criteria.name: Upfront Definition
criteria.description: Kill criteria defined before launch, not after emotional/financial investment

ratings.1: No kill criteria defined, or defined after project started
ratings.3: Kill criteria defined at launch but not formally documented or signed
ratings.5: Kill criteria defined in PRD before launch, signed by stakeholders, formally documented

criteria.name: Objectivity
criteria.description: Criteria use quantifiable metrics and thresholds, not subjective judgment

ratings.1: Subjective criteria (e.g., 'team feels it's not working', 'low adoption')
ratings.3: Mix of quantitative and qualitative criteria, some ambiguity
ratings.5: Fully objective criteria with specific numbers (e.g., '<10% conversion after 6 months', 'CAC >$200 for 3 months')

criteria.name: Decision Rights
criteria.description: Clear assignment of who makes kill decision, with escalation path

ratings.1: No clear decision-maker, 'team decides' or unclear ownership
ratings.3: Decision-maker named but no escalation path or override process
ratings.5: Specific person named as decision authority, clear escalation path, override process with limits

criteria.name: No Goalpost Moving
criteria.description: Kill criteria remain fixed; changes require formal justification and re-approval

ratings.1: Criteria change informally when approached, goalposts move frequently
ratings.3: Criteria mostly stable but some informal adjustments without documentation
ratings.5: Criteria fixed at launch, changes require written justification + senior approval + new document

criteria.name: Sunk Cost Avoidance
criteria.description: Decision based on future value, not past investment; uses pre-mortem inversion

ratings.1: Heavy focus on sunk costs ('invested too much to quit'), no counterfactual analysis
ratings.3: Acknowledges sunk costs but also considers future, limited use of inversion techniques
ratings.5: Explicitly uses pre-mortem inversion ('would we start this today?'), focuses only on future value

criteria.name: Execution Speed
criteria.description: Kill decision executed quickly (wind-down within 1 month), avoiding zombie projects

ratings.1: Projects linger for 3+ months after kill decision, zombie projects exist
ratings.3: Wind-down takes 1-2 months, some delays but eventual completion
ratings.5: Wind-down plan executed within 1 month: team reallocated, resources freed, postmortem completed

criteria.name: Opportunity Cost Consideration
criteria.description: Evaluates best alternative use of resources, quantifies opportunity cost

ratings.1: No consideration of alternatives, 'finish what we started' mentality
ratings.3: Mentions alternatives informally but no quantification or comparison
ratings.5: Explicitly compares current project to top 3 alternatives, quantifies EV/Cost ratio for each

criteria.name: Portfolio Thinking
criteria.description: Projects ranked and managed as portfolio, bottom performers killed to free resources

ratings.1: Projects evaluated individually, no portfolio ranking or rebalancing
ratings.3: Informal portfolio view but no systematic ranking or kill threshold
ratings.5: Quarterly portfolio ranking with explicit methodology, kill threshold (e.g., bottom 30%), active rebalancing

criteria.name: Postmortem Culture
criteria.description: Blameless postmortems conducted within 2 weeks, learnings shared, killing normalized

ratings.1: No postmortems, or blame-focused, killed projects hidden or stigmatized
ratings.3: Postmortems occur but sometimes delayed, limited sharing, some stigma remains
ratings.5: Blameless postmortems within 2 weeks, documented and shared widely, killing celebrated as discipline

criteria.name: Wind-Down Planning
criteria.description: Detailed wind-down plan prepared upfront, includes communication, reallocation, customer transition

ratings.1: No wind-down plan, ad-hoc execution when kill triggered, customers/team surprised
ratings.3: Basic wind-down plan exists but incomplete (missing communication or customer transition)
ratings.5: Comprehensive wind-down plan with communication timeline, team reallocation, customer transition, postmortem schedule

guidance_by_type.rationale: New products carry high uncertainty. Strong upfront kill criteria and wind-down planning prevent prolonged resource drain if product-market fit not achieved.
Features compete for engineering resources. Clear metrics, fast kill decisions, and opportunity cost analysis ensure resources flow to highest-impact features.
Experiments should have clear success/failure criteria upfront. Avoid sunk cost trap for failed experiments; learn systematically via postmortems.
Managing multiple projects requires disciplined ranking, rebalancing, and adherence to kill criteria. Portfolio optimization depends on killing bottom performers.
Building culture around disciplined stopping requires clear governance, blameless learning, and smooth wind-downs that preserve team morale.

guidance_by_complexity.notes: Focus on clear metrics defined upfront and fast execution. Complexity is low enough that informal decision rights acceptable.
Requires formal kill criteria document, named decision-maker, and detailed wind-down plan. Team size creates reallocation complexity.

guidance_by_complexity.complexity: Complex (portfolio of 5+ projects, or multi-year initiatives)
guidance_by_complexity.notes: Demands systematic portfolio management with quarterly rebalancing, strict adherence to criteria, opportunity cost analysis, and strong learning culture.

common_failure_modes.name: Moving Goalposts
common_failure_modes.symptom: When kill criteria approached, team extends timeline or lowers bar ('let's give it another 3 months')
common_failure_modes.detection: Compare current criteria to original PRD; check for informal changes without re-approval
common_failure_modes.fix: Lock criteria at launch with sign-off; require written justification + senior approval for any changes

common_failure_modes.name: Sunk Cost Justification
common_failure_modes.symptom: 'We've invested $2M/18 months, can't quit now' even though future prospects poor
common_failure_modes.detection: Listen for past-focused language ('invested', 'spent', 'too far to stop'); absence of opportunity cost analysis
common_failure_modes.fix: Apply pre-mortem inversion: 'If starting today with $0, would we do this?' Focus only on future value.

common_failure_modes.name: Subjective Criteria
common_failure_modes.symptom: Debates over whether 'low engagement' or 'poor adoption' triggers kill, no clear threshold
common_failure_modes.detection: Two people evaluating same data reach different conclusions; criteria use qualitative terms
common_failure_modes.fix: Quantify all criteria with specific numbers and dates (e.g., '<10% weekly active after 6 months')

common_failure_modes.name: Committee Decision-Making
common_failure_modes.symptom: 'Team decides' or 'we'll discuss' leads to paralysis, no one willing to make tough call
common_failure_modes.detection: Kill decision delayed for weeks/months despite criteria met; multiple meetings with no resolution
common_failure_modes.fix: Assign single decision-maker by name in kill criteria doc; decision-maker accountable for timely call

common_failure_modes.name: Zombie Projects
common_failure_modes.symptom: Projects linger in 'wind-down' for 3+ months, still consuming resources (time, attention, budget)
common_failure_modes.detection: Check wind-down duration; team members still partially allocated; infrastructure still running
common_failure_modes.fix: Set hard deadline for wind-down (1 month max); track completion; reallocate team immediately

common_failure_modes.name: Portfolio Inertia
common_failure_modes.symptom: Same projects continue year over year without reevaluation; no projects killed despite poor performance
common_failure_modes.detection: Portfolio composition unchanged for 2+ quarters; no active rebalancing or kill decisions
common_failure_modes.fix: Implement quarterly portfolio ranking; define kill threshold (bottom 20-30%); actively rebalance

common_failure_modes.name: No Postmortem
common_failure_modes.symptom: Killed projects immediately forgotten; no documentation of learnings; repeat same mistakes
common_failure_modes.detection: No postmortem docs; team can't articulate what went wrong; same failure patterns in new projects
common_failure_modes.fix: Require postmortem within 2 weeks of kill; document and share learnings; track pattern across projects

common_failure_modes.name: Stigma Around Killing
common_failure_modes.symptom: Teams reluctant to propose kill; PMs hide struggles; 'failure' language used; career concerns
common_failure_modes.detection: Projects linger past kill criteria; escalations delayed; teams defensive in reviews
common_failure_modes.fix: Leadership celebrates disciplined stopping; share kill decisions transparently; reward early recognition

common_failure_modes.name: After-the-Fact Criteria
common_failure_modes.symptom: Kill criteria defined after project launched; criteria adjusted to match current performance
common_failure_modes.detection: No kill criteria in original PRD; criteria added months into project; retroactive documentation
common_failure_modes.fix: Make kill criteria mandatory in PRD template; gate project approval on criteria definition; sign-off required

common_failure_modes.name: Ignoring Opportunity Cost
common_failure_modes.symptom: Continue project because 'almost done' even though resources could create more value elsewhere
common_failure_modes.detection: '80% complete' or 'just need to finish' justifications; no comparison to alternative uses
common_failure_modes.fix: Quantify opportunity cost; rank portfolio by EV/Cost ratio; kill if better alternatives exist regardless of completion

overall_guidance.excellent: Score ≥4.5: Exemplary discipline around stopping. Clear upfront criteria, objective metrics, decisive execution, portfolio thinking, strong learning culture. Organization skilled at capital allocation through disciplined killing.
overall_guidance.good: Score 3.5-4.4: Solid kill criteria and execution. Some areas for improvement (portfolio thinking, speed, or culture) but core discipline exists. Most projects have clear criteria and timely decisions.
overall_guidance.needs_improvement: Score <3.5: Significant gaps. Likely suffering from sunk cost fallacy, zombie projects, moved goalposts, or stigma around killing. Risk of prolonged resource drain on underperformers.
overall_guidance.key_principle: The hardest and most valuable skill is knowing when to quit. Organizations that kill projects decisively outperform those that let them linger. Sunk costs are irrelevant; only future value and opportunity cost matter.
